You say yes (I say yes)
 I say no (But I may mean no)
 You say stop (I can stay)
 And I say go go go (Till it’s time to go)
 Oh, oh no

It could be possible that Paul was writing about his differences with John, but disguising it with his play on words. It is interesting to think of it that way.



Life is filled with opposites,an action resulting in a reaction. This is classic pop song writing. The Beatles were very clever songwriters,the best in the business. There’s a kind of magical charm to the song, the music, the melody, the play on words. About as catchy as it gets.

Hela, heba helloa
 Hela, heba helloa, cha cha cha
 Hela, heba helloa, woo!
 Hela, heba helloa, hela!
 Hela, heba helloa, cha cha cha
 Hela, heba helloa, woo-hoo!
 Hela, heba helloa, cha cha cha
 Hela, heba helloa, cha cha cha

This was improvised in the studio. This part plays over the end credits of the Magical Mystery Tour movie.

Paul also punctuates that phrase with hah-cha, hah-cha, – a regional India phrase that loosely interprets to OK! or Alright! or Yes! in English.

I say high, you say low
 You say why and I say I don’t know, oh no

Shortly after this was released, McCartney explained:

The answer to everything is simple. It’s a song about everything and nothing. If you have black you have to have white. That’s the amazing thing about life.

You say goodbye and I say hello
 Hello, hello
 I don’t know why you say goodbye, I say hello
 Hello, hello
 I don’t know why you say goodbye, I say hello

Paul has a rocky relationship with this person, when he simply goes to greet them they comically say goodbye, not even wanting to engage with whatever Paul has to say.



John Lennon hated the song. He viewed it as an inconsequential song of McCartney’s, saying it was three minutes of contradictions and meaningless juxtapositions. What further infuriated Lennon was that his I Am The Walrus, was issued as the B-side to this.

You say yes, I say no
 You say stop and I say go go go, oh no

Paul McCartney wrote this. His friend Alistair Taylor, who was visiting McCartney, asked Paul one day how he wrote his many songs, and how he came up with his ideas.



Paul took him into his dining room to give him a demonstration of his hand-carved harmonium. As an experiment, Paul asked Taylor to shout out the opposite of whatever he sang, such as black and white, yes and no, hello and goodbye, etc. From this, the song was born.
